results.title: Hombre
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Martin Ritt and Irving Ravetch
results.brief_description: Paul Newman is the hero in this exciting, hard hitting western. John Russell is a white man raised as an Apache who faces the prejudices of a society which despises him. He is made to sit outside the stage coach by the white passengers who soon find that their lives are dependent on the man they rejected when outlaws leave them stranded in the desert. Co-starring Diane Cilento, Frederic March, Richard Boone and Barbara Rush.

results.title: Holzwege: wood roads/wrong ways
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and George Wallace-Crabbe
results.brief_description: Inspired by the diaries of a prisoner (in this case Nazi war criminal Albert Speer). In his daily exercise Speer began to measure the kilometres covered and projected his walk, in imaginative terms, across Southern Europe to Asia, Russia and the frozen Bering Strait. The film is constructed like a documentary of his imaginary journey. Holzwege, which translates as ‘wood road’ or ‘wrong way’ or ‘dead end’, was the pseudonym he used when signing the diaries.

results.title: Holy smoke
results.creator_credit: Miramax Films, Saddleback Productions, Jan Chapman and Jane Campion
results.brief_description: During a backpacking holiday in India, Ruth, a young Australian woman, experiences a spiritual awakening at an ashram. Convinced that she has found peace, harmony and purpose she decides to stay on with her newfound guru, much to the horror of her family in Australia. Luring her back to suburban Sydney on false pretences they employ the services of P.J., an American ‘cult-exiter’. The deprogramming encounter that takes place over three days in a shack on an isolated outback farm becomes a battle of wits and wills over spirituality and sexuality. Returning to the themes of dysfunctional family life that she focused on in her first feature “Sweetie”, Campion employs cultural stereotypes to contrast the exotic appeal of Eastern spiritualism for the idealistic Ruth, with her family’s lack of understanding and crassness. The film’s central concern with the search for the meaning of life is juxtaposed with comedic elements drawn from the repertoire of cliched Australian ‘types’ that were a commonplace of Australian cinema in the nineties, and moments of high melodrama. Though Campion clearly demonstrated her cinematic and technical proficiency, the narrative was considered by some critics to be somewhat clumsy and overambitious.

results.title: Holy rollers
results.creator_credit: Flamingo Star Films, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Sharyn Prentice and Rosie Jones
results.brief_description: Suzi Rosedale is an Australian woman living in an outer suburb of Jerusalem, offering guided tours of the city and surrounding areas for visitors on religious pilgrimages. This Australian made documentary follows Suzi on various trips as she takes groups of Mormons, Catholics, Jews and Muslims to the sites of Jesus’ life, literally following in his footsteps. The exact location where key events occurred are contested by various guides who offer differing opinions as to “the” place where, for example, Jesus was buried. Suzi calmly takes all things in her stride including a client in need of an unavailable can of Sprite with his dinner in a kibbutz. The need for the tourism industry to make money from such endeavours is matched by the emotional effect that the Holy Land has on its visitors. Technology meets ancient religious beliefs as Suzi escorts the tour around in an air-conditioned bus and each client is hooked up with a headset in order to hear Suzi’s commentary when on site. The commercial side of religious tours is exposed but not ridiculed in this entertaining documentary. Phillip Adams provides a comprehensive voice-over throughout. Filmed on video.

results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Roger Birnbaum and Stephen Herek
results.brief_description: An examination and re-evaluation of morals and ethics drives this comedy/drama about a television executive and a marketing manager who despite loathing each other, must work together. results.title: Holy Himalayas
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films of India, M. Bhavnani and K Khandpur
results.brief_description: A pilgrimage to the Hindu holy Badrinath and Kedarnath, in the Garwhal district of Uttar Pradesh. These have been centres of pilgrimage through the ages, are visited by thousands every year, who climb on foot through the Himalayan Mountains, near the Tibetan border. Shows something of the life of the district and the nature of Hindu devotion.

results.title: Holocaust
results.creator_credit: Israel Film Service, Yigal Efrati, Daivid Shitz and Ben Kerner
results.brief_description: This documentary traces the history of Nazism from its earliest roots in 1918 and focuses on the antisemetic nature of its doctrines. The rich cultural, religious and social world of Eastern Europe with its large numbers of Jewish people were destroyed by the evil flames of the Holocaust. The horror of the concentration camps, the bravery of the resistance fighters of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising and the Jewish partisans who desperately tried to save their people is documented in this moving analysis of what remains one of the greatest crimes in human history: the deliberate and systematic attempt to exterminate human beings on the grounds of race, colour and religion.

results.title: Hollywood: the Selznick years
results.brief_description: Shows the typical Hollywood of the 1930’s and 1940’s through the work of David O. Selznick. Includes footage from several films, commentary by some of the stars, tapes and rare footage of screen tests for “Rebecca” and “Gone with the wind” and the only existing film of Laurette Taylor and Maude Adams (actresses). A useful springboard for discussion. Aspects of the film which would make it useful include the Jewish producer role in the US at a time when Nazism was strong in Europe. Overall commentary by Henry Fonda.
